A character in a novel by this author receives a surprise blowjob from a girl he calls Juliet only to be abruptly asked about Ezra Pound by her when he ejaculates. A character created by this author has an affair with a one-breasted Venezuelan TV actress but is disgusted when she reveals that she'd had a lesbian relationship. A novel by this author opens with a boy recalling the first time he'd climbed a staircase upon moving to a city with his Communist parents. This author used many parenthetical asides introducing ironic wordplay in a novel in which a teenager has numerous thrilling sexual encounters with local tenement girls and movie theater prostitutes in the (*) pre-revolution 1940s and 50s in his country's capital city. While in exile in London, this author wrote a 1979 novel titled in Spanish for a piece by Ravel but published in English with the title [his name]'sInferno. For 10 points, name this Cuban novelist who wrote Three Trapped Tigers.

questions.text: This poem's author addresses a place as "war-queen" with "iron railing" and "granite carapace"; that "proud young city" in this poem is built by a ruler intending to "break a window to the West." This poem ends in a "frail cottage" with the discovery of the "chill corpse" of a man who had earlier found a willow tree in place of a house. In this poem, that man roams the streets for a year and climbs on top of a "marble pair of guardian (*) lions" to escape a flood. After discovering that the home of his lover Parasha has been destroyed, Yevgeny curses this work's title object, which comes to life and chases him. For 10 points, name this poem, a "Petersburg Tale" about an equestrian statue by Alexander Pushkin.
In which of the parts that Tolkien originally divided the book in do Aragorn, Gimli, and Legolas decide to go after Merry and Pippin in The Two Towers?

The observation that "they have taken the plants away" from the tomb of an American Symbolist poet with this surname begins a poem from John Ashbery's collection Self-Portrait in a Convex Mirror. In one poem, a poet with this surname described a "World that shifts like sand" whose "Potentate had lacked a retinue" right before the speaker exclaims, "Lo! it assembles on the shrinking Green." In that poem by an author with this surname, the speaker remarks, "Quite a task, / Putting together Heaven, yet we do." That poet with this surname wrote the collection Divine Comedies, which contains a poem whose speaker has a French governess he calls "Mademoiselle" who helps him complete a jigsaw puzzle. For 10 points, give this surname of the American poet of "Lost in Translation" and The Changing Light at Sandover.

acceptable: James Ingram Merrill; accept Stuart Merrill
Stuart Fitzrandolph Merrill; accept "The Tomb of Stuart Merrill"

questions.text: In a novel from this country, Rengganis enters her classroom naked while shouting about being assaulted by a dog in the school toilet. In another novel from this country, the one-legged artist Jean Marais ("mah-RAY") helps the protagonist avoid an obese hitman nicknamed Fatso. A magical realist novel from this country focusing on a prostitute who returns from the dead is titled Beauty is a Wound. A novel from this country about the native boy Minke's love for the mixed-race concubine's daughter Annelies was dictated by its author from prison. This modern-day country is the setting of This Earth of Mankind and a novel about the coffee trader Max Havelaar. For 10 points, what country is the birthplace of authors Eka Kurniawan and Pramoedya Ananta Toer ("pra-MOOD-yah ah-nahn-tah TOOR"), whose characters speak Dutch, Malay, and Javanese?

acceptable: Republik Indonesia; prompt on Dutch East Indies

questions.text: In what novel by Dick Francis does the popular character Sid Halley first appear?
The characters in this novel included Hester Prynne, Pearl, Roger Chillingworth and Arthur Dimmsdale.

The biography of Nobel prize winning economist and mathematician John Nash, written by Sylvia Nasar, inspired this 2001 movie directed by Ron Howard, which was nominated for 8 Academy awards and won four of them.

This poet described how if a poem has "a genius" it will "force its own reception" in a poem that criticized a contemporary conspiracy set "in pious times, ere priest-craft did begin." This poet sarcastically wished a fellow poet "some peaceful province" where he can "torture one poor word ten thousand ways." After converting to Catholicism, this poet represented the different English churches as animals in (*) The Hind and the Panther. A disagreement about the legacy of Ben Jonson led this poet to write a mock-epic about the dullness of Thomas Shadwell. For 10 points, name this first Poet Laureate of England who wrote the satires Absalom and Achitophel ("uh-KIT-oh-fell") and MacFlecknoe.

A narrator who visits the "White Friar" William Southfield then hears this author cite tears of contrition as proof of the Holy Ghost in that autobiographical narrator, who self-identifies with the phrase "this creature." This author's "Short Text" omits the parable of a servant who falls in a ditch and passages about "Christ our Mother." This author recounted receiving "all that is" in the form of a "little thing, the size of a (*) hazelnut." The poem "Little Gidding" quotes this writer's statement that "All shall be well, and all manner of thing shall be well." Margery Kempe wrote of visiting this author of the earliest surviving English book by a woman, which records sixteen "showings." For 10 points, Revelations of Divine Love is by what anchoress who lived in Norwich?
This is the way they ring the bells in Bedlam
So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back into the past. was  the last line in a book by this  author.
This book led Austin Miles to the courts in 1992.  Miles was sued because his book was ...a vitriolic attack upon organized Christianity.

This author created Uncle Doaker, a rail worker who describes how his family history was carved into an object Boy Willie tries to sell. A character created by this author can't read, causing his brother to be sent to an asylum, but that brother returns and tries to blow a trumpet at a funeral. In a play by this author, Berenice Charles learns how to play an (*) instrument to exorcize the ghost of a slave owner named Sutter. This author of The Piano Lesson wrote a play in which Cory's football scholarship is sabotaged by his garbage truck driver-father, Troy Maxson. For 10 points, name this author whose Pittsburgh Cycle of plays includes Fences.

A character of this ethnicity cuts her daughter's tongue so she can "speak in any language." An author of this ethnicity wrote about a "Girlhood Among Ghosts" in her folktale-infused memoir, The Woman Warrior. The "art of invisible strength" is used to win chess games by a character of this ethnicity, (*) Waverly. Sections like "The Twenty-Six Malignant Gates" organize a novel about San Francisco women of this ethnicity who play board games at the Joy Luck Club. For 10 points, name this ethnicity shared by Maxine Hong Kingston and Amy Tan.

questions.text: Piers Anthonys fantasy land of Xanth looks strikingly similar to what southern state of the USA?

In a story by this author, a character in the midst of translating a work by Jose Norberto Allende begins imagining seeing a woman's hands move. In a novel by this author, two men build a bridge between their windows as a way to deliver yerba and nails. The narrator in one of this author's stories repeatedly visits the Jardin des plantes ("zhar-DAN duh PLAHNT") to see the title animals. Michel takes and (*) enlarges a photograph of what he believes to be an illicit liaison between a woman and a boy in this author's story "Blow-Up." The Serpent Club tries to piece together a novel by Morelli that could be read out of order in a metafictional novel by this author. For 10 points, name this Argentinian author of Hopscotch.

This novel is narrated by the fictional character Frank Chambers, a drifter who stops at a roadside diner and meets ‘femme fatale’, Cora. After starting an affair, Cora and Frank murder Cora’s husband, Nick Papadakis, who is the owner of the diner.
This famous anti-war novel by Erik Marie Remarque was banned in Nazi Germany.

answer.primary: All Quiet on the Western Front

mcqOptions: All Quiet on the Western Front

questions.text: In a story by this author, a man insults his future stepmother by calling her 100 years old, then cuts off her retorts by throwing mud at her. A character created by this author invents a ruse to marry a farmer's daughter involving a cursed jacket that is heralded by the appearance of a pig's head. At the end of a story by this author, a ghost shakes his fist at a timid watchman, having earlier haunted a person of importance who had scolded a clerk out of his office. This author included "The Fair at Sorochyntsi ("sah-rah-CHIN-seh") in the collection Evenings on a Farm Near Dikanka. This author wrote a story in which the copyist Akaky Akakievich obsessively saves money to buy a new garment. For 10 points, name this Russian author of "The Overcoat."

An Archdeacon created by this playwright whose wife is blind, deaf, goutish, dementia-afflicted, and unable to eat solid food appears in a play that ends with a man finding, and not recognizing, his father's glove. A novel by Robert Hichens is titled for the flower that this author supposedly told his followers to wear for the premiere of one of his plays. At the end of a play by this author, the Puritan Hester Worsley becomes engaged to the illegitimate son of (*) Lord Illingworth. In one of this author's plays, the idea that "we are all in the gutter, but some of us are looking at the stars" is said by Lord Darlington, whose affair is nearly revealed when the title object is found in his apartment. For 10 points, name this playwright of A Woman of No Importance and Lady Windermere's Fan.

answer.primary: Oscar Wilde  (The Hichens novel is The Green Carnation.)

questions.text: In one play, this character opposes a god by proclaiming "your whole universe is not enough to prove me wrong" and "you are not the king of man." That "God of Death," Demetrios, attempts to discourage this character who goes by the name Philebus. In another play, Apollo commands this character and his cousin Pylades to return to their home city. In that play, this character leaves a (*) lock of his hair at a grave, where it is found by his sister. This character is acquitted by Athena after being pursued by the Furies for killing his mother Clytemnestra. For 10 points, name this brother of Electra who titles an Aeschylus trilogy.

answer.primary: Orestes  (The work in the first line is The Flies by J.P. Sartre)
acceptable: Orestis; accept The Oresteia; prompt on Philebus before read

questions.text: In a poem from a collection titled for this author, the speaker says, "Decapitating the spring onions, / She made this mental note: / You can tell it's love, the real thing, / When you dream of slitting his throat." This author wrote, "Women are really much nicer than men: / No wonder we like them" in the poem "The Bookshop Idyll." In a collection titled for this author, a street lamp says, "'Remark the mouse that races towards the carpet'" as the speaker repeats "Hickory dickory" in a "Nursery Rhyme" parody of a different author. A poem in a collection titled for this author ends, (*) "I hope you'll make sense of the notes." The speaker says, "I knew it wouldn't be much of a poem / But I love the title" in a collection titled for this author that includes the fictional poet Jason Strugnell. For 10 points, name this English author who was part of the Movement, and whom Wendy Cope wrote about Making Cocoa for in one collection.

answer.primary: Kingsley Amis  (The poems clued are "From June to December," "A Nursery Rhyme (as it might have been written by T.S. Eliot)," "Waste Land Limericks," and "Making Cocoa for Kingsley Amis," respectively.)

questions.text: A character in one story in this collection recounts his time as a pirate when he had five wives and a schooner named La Belle Eliza. A story-within-a-story called "The Wine of the Tetrarch" is told by Cardinal Hamilcar, who reveals himself to be the Kasparson, at the end of a story in this collection. Miss Malin and (*) Countess Calypso are among the four people trapped in a hayloft who tell stories during a flood on the title island in that story in this collection. In another story from this collection, the ghost of Morten visits his sisters Eliza and Fanny, who prepare the title meal. "The Supper at Elsinore" and "The Deluge at Norderney" are stories in, for 10 points, what collection by Isak Dinesen?

This book features an annoying Texan roommate who scalds himself when he throws the contents of a boiling pot of water in the air to test the Midwestern myth that it will freeze before hitting the ground. This book's narrator makes a series of ironic grimaces when breaking up with his longtime girlfriend Pen. The narrator of this novel gets bored out of his mind after taking a lucrative job in Minnesota and living by himself in a mostly empty McMansion. The climax of this novel sees its narrator repeatedly photographed and humiliated by a man wearing a Brazilian football jersey while at a bar with his love interest, a photographer whose attempts to break up with him are part of an elaborate conceptual art piece. This novel, which opens with the line (*) "I like hurting girls," follows the nameless confessional narrator who is a reformed alcoholic and serial emotional abuser of his many girlfriends. For 10 points, name this 2006 bestselling novel that purports to be the memoir of an Irish sociopathic advertising executive, which was published by a Dutch author writing as "Anonymous."
What was the name of the handsome, selfish teacher in Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets?
This fun little charm from the Harry Potter series produces a lovely bouquet of flowers.
What Shakespearean tragedy, set in Denmark, explores the themes of treachery and revenge?

These two characters first appeared in two stories that were rewritten from stories about Reggie Pepper, one of which was rewritten about another character, Mr. Mulliner. One of these characters writes about meeting celebrities in New York clubs for "Rocky," and accidentally takes his aunt to a talk denouncing the evils of the city. In another story featuring these characters, one allows the other to shave his mustache, being impressed by his suggestion to blackmail the Duke of Chiswick after he refuses to shake hands with eighty-seven men. That duke's nephew, Bicky, decides to become a chicken farmer in a story titled for one of these two characters and (*) "the Hard-Boiled Egg." These two characters are tasked by Aunt Agatha with saving her nephew from becoming a vaudeville performer in New York in "Extricating Young Gussie." For 10 points, name these characters, an idle rich gentleman and his valet, created by P. G. Wodehouse.

questions.text: In the books Eragon and Eldest, wierda is the ancient language word meaning fate.

A man asks "Do you think that the soul first shows itself by a gnashing of teeth?" while witnessing some of these characters undergo a "cramp." Busman is electrocuted aboard the ship Ultimus while trying to negotiate peace during a rebellion of these characters led by (*) Radius. Helena Glory burns the manuscript to create these beings. After two of these characters swear to give their lives for each other, Alquist dubs them the new Adam and Eve. The term for these beings was first coined by Rossum in the play R.U.R. by Karel Capek ("kah-REL CHA-pek"). For 10 points, name these artificial beings.

acceptable: Rossum's Universal Robots; prompt on R.U.R.; prompt on answers like androids
machines, since we're looking for a specific term

questions.text: Who wrote the novel Gone With the Wind?

In one novel by an author born in this country, an anarchist becomes a Jesuit after the burning of an all-female hostel. A nun from this country authored the psychological treatise "The Transfiguration of the Commonplace" after ending an affair with a one-armed artist. This is the birth country of the novelist of The Girls of Slender Means, who created a set of schoolgirls dubbed the creme-de-la-creme by the (*) fascist-sympathizing teacher Miss Jean ("jeen") Brodie. In a novel from this birth country of Muriel Spark, the title character saves the Jewish nurse Rebecca from burning at the stake and is helped by the disguised Black Knight to marry Lady Rowena - that novel is Ivanhoe. For 10 points, name this home country of Robert Burns and Walter Scott.

This author included the recurring line "she looked over his shoulder" in a poem about a man "who would not live long." The lines "What mad Nijinsky wrote / About Diaghilev / Is true of the normal heart" appear in a poem by this author that ends with "an affirming flame." This author described (*) "ironic points of light" and "blind skyscrapers" in a different poem. One poem by this author of The Age of Anxiety and "The Shield of Achilles" opens, "I sit in one of the dives / on Fifty-second Street" and states, "We must love one another or die." For 10 points, what British-American poet wrote "September 1, 1939"?

While accepting the 1976 Neustadt Prize, one author remarked that most of her books had titles relating to this discipline after comparing herself to the sandpiper in one of her poems. One poem concludes that a form of this discipline "displays no favorites" and that "More delicate than the historians'" are the "colors" used by people in this discipline. Since a final collection titled for this discipline only consisted of 10 poems, the publisher had to widen its margins to make it book-length; that collection contains a poem in which (*) Robinson Crusoe is cursed to record flora, fauna, and data relating to this field after having a Darwinian dream of infinite islands. The three epigraphs to one poetry collection quote three questions and answers from an elementary school textbook on this topic, the last answer of which is "land and water." A girl is reading a magazine partially titled for this discipline as she thinks of "those awful hanging breasts" and hears an "oh of pain" from her Aunt Consuelo in the poem "In the Waiting Room." For 10 points, an Elizabeth Bishop collection containing "One Art" is titled for what subject followed by the number 3?

acceptable: map-making; accept Geography III; accept National Geographic

questions.text: Dorothy Parker wrote movie reviews for which magazine?

A comment that this series, which Robert Cadell published in a "Magnum Opus" edition, has "too many" entries was made by Benedetto Croce and cited in Dwight Macdonald's "Masscult and Midcult." In lecture two of Aspects of the Novel, Forster summarizes a novel in this series in which a charlatan plants treasure in the ruins on Arthur's land. It was an open secret who wrote many of these novels that were published as "by the author of" their first entry, which include The (*) Antiquary and the Chronicles of the Canongate but not always the Tales of My Landlord subseries. 'TisSixty Years Since is the subtitle of the first of these novels, which include the story of Lady Rebecca and Rowena's aid of El Desdichado, who helps the Black Knight who turns out to be King Richard. For 10 points, what series of novels including Ivanhoe were penned by Sir Walter Scott?

acceptable: the Waverley series; prompt on Chronicles of the Canongate and Tales of My Landlord before mention; prompt on Tales of the Crusades

questions.text: Often coming in at number one on 100 Best Novels of the 20th Century lists, what is the name of the James Joyce book that depicts a day in the life of Leopold Bloom?
mcqOptions: A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man

questions.text: The main character of this novel can make people disappear from existence with an effort of will.
In Night life of the Gods by Thorne Smith what object is responsible for the transformations that occur throughout the story?

In the last work in this medium from one novel, the siblings Sister Fatima and Richard survive a 100-year fire only to die by falling through a trapdoor. One work in this medium ends with Sergeant Lituma holding a gun to a man's head trying to decide whether to shoot. After failing to obtain them from Cuba, one company hires a local writer to create works in this medium that form (*) alternating chapters of a novel in which the protagonist courts a 32-year-old divorcee. Pedro Camacho and Marito both write scripts for this medium for Panamericana in Mario Vargas Llosa's Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter. For 10 points, name this medium used for a 1938 reading of H. G. Wells' The War of the Worlds that purportedly caused a mass panic.

acceptable: radio plays; accept scripts until "Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter" is read; prompt on serials by asking "what type of serials?"

questions.text: A character in this work is emphasized with the lines "Never again would he glitter and glide / And show himself off in the midnight air." A version of this work published by Maria Dahvana Headley begins it with the word "Bro!." One character in this work dies from fighting the Shyflings after he and his wife (*) Hygd are given treasure. In this work, the sound from the mead-hall Herot ("HAY-oh-rot") of King Hrothgar caused a demon to terrorize the Danes, culminating in the eventual defeat of the demon and his mother by the title hero. For 10 points, name this epic poem in Old English whose title hero slays Grendel.
Humbert Humbert is the protagonist and narrator of which 1955 novel?

The brief marriage between this novel's author and an architecture school classmate may have inspired its description of a character's failed marriage to Larry McCaslin. In this novel, the observation "it is best to be prepared" is one of "Two Thoughts" sealed in a jam container. A metaphor used by the Rhodes Scholar Chacko in this novel leads its narrator to refer to an abandoned hut as the (*) History House. During a screening of The Sound of Music, a character in this novel is molested in a cinema by the Orangedrink Lemondrink Man. This novel's "Love Laws" are broken when Ammu falls in love with Velutha ("VEL-oo-tuh"), a Dalit. For 10 points, name this debut novel by Arundhati ("uh-ROON-duh-tee") Roy whose protagonists are the twins Estha and Rahel.
Mark David Chapman was found with a copy of The Catcher in the Rye on the night he shot this person.

The geneticist Victor Hoppe returns to his childhood home in small-town Belgium with three identical children in tow in a Stefan Brijs novel titled for a "maker" of these characters. One of these characters titles and narrates a novel in which the public prosecutor Alberegt strikes and kills a little girl with his Renault while rushing to get to a trial during the German invasion of his country. In one novel, intermezzos in which some of these characters comment on the main action are intercut with scenes about a love triangle between the cellist Ada Brons, the linguist Onno, and the astronomer Max in The Hague. A character of this type (*) "recalls" in the English title of a novel by Willem Frederik Hermans. In a long philosophical novel, two of these characters select a Spark and use DNA editing to design a body for Quinten, who is tasked with finding the Ten Commandments tablets and returning them to the title place. For 10 points, what sort of non-human beings appear in Harry Mulisch's novel The Discovery of Heaven?

acceptable: a guardian angel; accept The Angel Maker

In a novel with this substance in its title, a man thinks of Heinrich von Kleist's love-suicide at Wannsee on a hungover morning walk after his unrequited crush turned him out of her house when they woke up next to each other. This substance partially titles that novel, in which a man from Ankara sent to learn soapmaking in Berlin falls for the assertive portrait painter Maria. This material and a "Madonna" title a 1943 novel by the Turkish author Sabahattin Ali. This material partially titles a book in which a man assumes the guise of a Russian servant named Gregor while in Florence, where he is (*) humiliated by the ultra-masculine Alexis Papadopolis as part of a series of "supersensual" experiences. In that novella partially titled for this material, Wanda von Dunajew takes on a submissive sex slave named Severin. questions.text: In this novel, a man declares "there ain't no sin and there ain't no virtue. There's just stuff people do" when describing how he always slept with women after church. Passages describing how "the smell of rot fills the country" and "the men sat still - thinking - figuring" are among this novel's sixteen "inner chapters." A woman threatens her son with a jack handle for suggesting to split their family up in this novel. At this novel's end, a woman gives birth in a flooding (*) boxcar and breastfeeds a starving man. This novel's protagonist goes on the run after clubbing a man who murdered an ex-preacher and labor organizer, Jim Casy. For 10 points, Tom Joad travels to California during the Dust Bowl in what John Steinbeck novel?

The title character of a novel by this author moves to Virginia after marrying Lady Castlewood. This author of Henry Esmond wrote a picaresque novel about a member of the Irish gentry who adopts the name Barry Lyndon. William Dobbin and Amelia (*) Sedley marry after the death of George Osborne in a novel by this author set around the time of the Battle of Waterloo. This author wrote a "novel without a hero" about a woman who attends Miss Pinkerton's Academy. For 10 points, name this author who wrote about Becky Sharp in Vanity Fair.

questions.text: A poem about this person is parodied by another poem that mentions a man whom "double-trumpet symmetry Riemann did not court" since "His tastes [go] to simpler-curvedness, the buxom Teuton sort!" That parody of an older poem originally about this person by Roger Zelazny replaces a line about him with one about Lobachevsky. This person titles a poem that ends by mentioning "A silent child [who] stood by them / From morning until noon / Because they drew such charming / Round pictures of the moon." That Vachel Lindsay poem features this person observed by "solemn greybeards" as he "drew a (*) circle on a sand-beach long ago." A poem mentioning this person proclaims "let geese / Gabble and hiss, but heroes seek release / From dusty bondage into luminous air," before closing by mentioning a feminine personified figure with a "massive sandal set on stone." For 10 points, according to a sonnet by Edna St. Vincent Millay, what Greek man "alone has looked on beauty bare?"

A literary almanac in this language titled after the epic poem May was founded by the poet of Cosmic Songs. A movement in this language named for the butterbur plant gave birth to "poetism," a style adopted by the author of the collection The Nightingale Sings Badly.
